entry.name: 29RNP phosphorylation site
entry.description: Identfication 29RNP phosphorylation site by rice chloroplast CK2 alpha.

additional_fields.field: For identification the RNP phosphorylation site, the phosphorylation reaction was performed in vitro as mentioned before. Then the RNP protein were loaded to SDS PAGE and stained. The band of RNP were cut and in-gel digested by trypsin. The phosphorylation peptides were enriched by Magnetic TiO2 beads (Thermo Scientific. USA). Dried peptides were resuspended in 5% ACN and 0.3% formic acid and analyzed on a LTQ-Oribtrap mass spectrometer (Thermo Fischer Scientific) with a nanoelectropspray ion source. Peptides were separated with an Eksigent nano LC system (Eksigent Technologies), equipped with an 12-cm fused silica emitter (75μm i.d.) packed with a reversed phase C18 resin (3-μm particles, 120-Å pore size, SunChrom, Friedrichsdorf, Germany). The flow rate was 600 nl/min. The peptide mixture was separated and eluted by a gradient from 5 to 65 % ACN over 1 h followed by an increase up to 80% during an additional 7 min. Nano-ESI was accomplished with a spray voltage of 2.5 kV and a heated capillary temperature of 230 °C. A cycle of one full-scan mass spectrum (400–2000 m/z) followed by five data-dependent MS/MS spectra was repeated continuously. All MS/MS spectra were acquired using the following parameters: normalized collision energy, 35%; ion selection threshold, 1e5 counts. Selected ions were dynamically excluded for 30 s. The application of mass spectrometer scan functions and HPLC solvent gradients were controlled by an XCalibur data system (Thermo Fisher Scientific).

MS and MS/MS spectra were search against the Rice database containing common contaminants such as keratin using MASCOT 2.4 (Matrix Science). The fixed modification was set to carbamylation of Cys residues and the variable modifications were set to oxidation of Met and phosphorylation of Ser, Thr and Tyr. With MASCOT, database searches were restricted to tryptic peptides missing maximal one cleavage site and protein C- and N-terminal peptides, allowing for 2+ and 3+ charged peptides a parent mass error tolerance of 5 ppm and a daughter ion error tolerance of 0.6 D. Identifications were accepted with a MASCOT ion score of 40 or greater and a MASCOT expect value of less than 0.01. The identified phosphor-peptides was also analyzed by PhosCalc based on software manual(MacLean et al., 2008).

Lu Q, Ding S, Reiland S, Rödiger A, Roschitzki B, Xue P, Gruissem W, Lu C, Baginsky S. Identification and characterization of chloroplast casein kinase II from Oryza sativa (rice). J Exp Bot. 2015 Jan;66(1):175-87
